Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Summer Undergraduate Research Program in Biochemistry
Award.AbstractNarration: The Texas A&M University Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics REU Site will provide a research program for undergraduates during the summers of 2009-2013. Twelve students will be selected to participate in a 10-week research experience in biochemistry. The major goals of this program are to prepare students to pursue graduate training and careers in research, and to instill in those students an appreciation of the effort and satisfaction involved in this pursuit. Students will be trained in a diverse array of modern biochemical methods in a vibrant department, and will develop effective oral and written communication skills to describe their scientific projects. Recruiting efforts are focused on students who have completed their junior or sophomore year at colleges and universities in Texas and mid-Southern states, particularly those from institutions that do not offer doctoral degrees. Applications from students in underrepresented minority groups are particularly encouraged. Undergraduate participants will perform cutting-edge research in biochemistry while integrated into pre-existing laboratory groups of graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, undergraduate students and technicians. At the conclusion of the program the students will present their research accomplishments in both written and oral reports. More information is available at http://biochemistry.tamu.edu/?ch=reu, or by contacting Mary Bryk at bryk@tamu.edu or the Program Director, Dr. Gary Kunkel at g-kunkel@tamu.edu.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT FOR THE GENERAL PUBLIC

 

We administered a NSF-REU program in biochemistry in the Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics at Texas A&M University during the summers of 2009 through 2013. This Summer Undergraduate Research Program in Biochemistry lasted almost 10 weeks and coincided with the summer session at the university. 10-12 students who had completed their junior or sophomore year in college were recruited annually from universities and colleges throughout the U.S., particularly from institutions that do not offer doctoral degrees. Special recruiting efforts were made to attract students from universities and colleges in Texas and surrounding states in the mid-South region. Within this region several partner institutions that enroll substantial numbers of underrepresented minority students were asked to identify students to submit applications to the program. During the period of this grant, 489 students submitted applications and 54 students were supported by NSF funds. Ten additional students participated with funding provided by other sources that included Texas A&M University, or the American Chemical Society. The pool of participants was diverse, with 56% female, and 36% from ethnic groups underrepresented in science and engineering.

 

The intellectual merit of this program is based on the participation of undergraduate students in cutting-edge research in biochemistry. The Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics at Texas A&M University offers an energetic atmosphere to perform research in diverse areas of biochemistry, including, but not limited to, bioinformatics, genomics and proteomics, enzymology, structural biology, mechanisms of gene expression, membrane structure and function, and developmental/cell biology. Undergraduate participants received training from faculty advisors who direct nationally-funded research programs. Weekly meetings provided training in research ethics, critical analysis of research literature, development of hypothesis-driven research and instruction in presentation skills. At the conclusion of the program the students presented their research accomplishments in both written and oral reports.

 

Very significant broader impacts resulted from the summer research program. REU students departed with an appreciation of the effort and satisfaction involved in biochemical research, and were prepared to pursue graduate training and careers in this area. Many participants enrolled subsequently in graduate school or obtained research assistant positions in academia or industry. At one year after participation in our program at least 44% had enrolled in graduate programs in science or were employed in research positions. We note that 18% were still undergraduate students, and a high percentage of these students were likely to enroll later in graduate degree programs. Participant ratings of our program were high. Using a 5-point scale with 5 being the highest, participants reported with annual ratings between 4.57 and 4.92 that “this program helped me to increase my research skills.” Likewise, annual ratings between 4.57 and 5.0 responded to the query of “I would recommend this program to others.”

 

At present, our summer research program is being supported by another NSF-REU renewal grant, and we look forward to continuing the training of a diverse group of undergraduate students for future careers in science.
